data.event: In England, on 29 August 1840, Henry Dendy (1800–81) purchased 5,120 acres (2,070 ha) of Port Phillip land at £1 per acre, site unseen, under the terms of the short-lived Special Survey regulations.
Dendy arrived on 5 February 1841 to claim his land.
A town was surveyed in mid-1841, defined by the crescent-shaped street layout which remains today, and subdivided allotments were offered for sale.
The family of his agent Jonathan Binns Were (1809–85) who had arrived in Melbourne in 1839, bought the land.
